Title: Real effects of a widespread CSR reporting mandate: Evidence from the European Union's CSR Directive*
Authors: P. Fiechter, Jörg-Markus Hitz, Nico Lehmann
Abstract summary: The EU's CSR reporting mandate led to increased CSR activities by affected firms, especially those with previously low CSR reporting and activities.

Title: Corporate Social Responsibility Report Narratives and Analyst Forecast Accuracy
Authors: Volkan Muslu, Sunay Mutlu, S. Radhakrishnan, Albert H. C. Tsang
Abstract summary: CSR report narratives with higher disclosure scores are associated with more accurate analyst forecasts.

Title: Do shareholders reward or punish risky firms due to CSR reporting and assurance?
Authors: Ali Uyar, S. Pizzi, F. Caputo, C. Kuzey, Abdullah S. Karaman
Abstract summary: Shareholders reward risky firms for CSR reporting if it is assured and follows the GRI framework.

Title: Corporate social responsibility reporting in China: political, social and corporate influences
Authors: Sepideh Parsa, N. Dai, A. Belal, Teng Li, Guliang Tang
Abstract summary: CSR reporting in China is influenced by political, social, and corporate factors, helping companies gain legitimacy domestically and globally.

Title: Corporate social responsibility and classification shifting
Authors: Juhee Hwang, Sera Choi, Sunhwa Choi, Yong Gyu Lee
Venue: Journal of Accounting and Public Policy
Abstract summary: Firms with good CSR performance are less likely to engage in classification shifting to inflate core earnings.

Title: The expansion of non-financial reporting: an exploratory study
Authors: Hervé Stolowy, Luc Paugam
Abstract summary: The paper explores the expansion of non-financial reporting, including corporate social responsibility (CSR) reporting, and the factors that influence CSR reporting practices.

Title: Quality choices in corporate social responsibility reporting under heterogeneous investor preferences
Authors: Akihiro Noda
Venue: Journal of Accounting and Public Policy
Abstract summary: Firms choose the quality of their CSR reporting to target socially responsible investors.

Title: Counter-reporting sustainability from the bottom up: the case of the construction company WeBuild and dam-related conflicts
Authors: A. Bontempi, Daniela Del Bene, L. D. Di Felice
Abstract summary: The paper examines the discrepancy between a construction company's CSR narratives and the socio-environmental impacts of its projects.

Title: Corporate Social Responsibility and Financial Reporting Quality: Evidence from Restatements
Authors: Yi‐Hung Lin, H. Huang, Mark Riley, Chih-Chen Lee
Abstract summary: Higher corporate social responsibility (CSR) scores are associated with lower probability of financial statement restatements, but this relationship disappeared in the 2006-2012 period.

Title: Do CSR performance and reporting facilitate access to debt financing in emerging markets? The role of asset structure and firm performance
Authors: Ali Uyar, A. Gerged, C. Kuzey, Abdullah S. Karaman
Abstract summary: CSR performance and reporting facilitate access to debt financing in emerging markets, with asset structure and firm performance as moderating factors.

Title: Preventive and Remedial Actions in Corporate Reporting Among “Addiction Industries”: Legitimacy, Effectiveness and Hypocrisy Perception
Authors: Diletta Acuti, M. Bellucci, Giacomo Manetti
Abstract summary: This paper examines how companies in "addiction industries" like tobacco, alcohol, and gambling use CSR reporting to manage organizational legitimacy and stakeholder perceptions.

Title: Erratum to: Enhancing the Role and Effectiveness of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Reports: The Missing Element of Content Verification and Integrity Assurance
Authors: S. Sethi, Terrence F. Martell, Mert C. Demir
Abstract summary: CSR reporting lacks robust measures to ensure quality and accuracy of content, which this paper attempts to address.

Title: Firm Responses to Nonprescriptive Pollution Regulation: Evidence from China’s Corporate Social Responsibility Reporting Mandate
Authors: J. Gramlich, Li Huang
Abstract summary: China's mandatory CSR reporting requirement led to reduced pollution levels, with mixed effects on firm profitability.

Title: Investor response to corporate social responsibility performance: The role of corporate social responsibility reports readability
Authors: Zhaoxuan Sun, Shu‐Ning Wang, Dongdong Li
Abstract summary: CSR reporting with high readability amplifies the positive investor response to a company's CSR performance.

Title: The Political Ontology of Corporate Social Responsibility: Obscuring the Pluriverse in Place
Authors: Maria Ehrnström-Fuentes, S. Böhm
Abstract summary: CSR reporting enables corporations to singularize and represent their place-making practices, obscuring alternative world-making practices.

Title: Corporate Reputation in The Spanish Context: An Interaction Between Reporting to Stakeholders and Industry
Authors: Andrea Pérez, Maria del Mar García de los Salmones, C. López
Abstract summary: CSR reporting is especially relevant and useful in the finance industry in Spain, where it is more closely linked to corporate reputation.

Title: Corporate Tax Avoidance and Corporate Social Responsibility Disclosure Readability: Evidence from China
Authors: Shuo Xu, Fangjun Wang, C. Cullinan, N. Dong
Abstract summary: Tax-avoiding companies use more readable CSR reporting to restore legitimacy.

Title: CSR Restatements: Mischief or Mistake?
Authors: Rebecca L. Bachmann, Helen Spiropoulos
Abstract summary: Contracting on CSR metrics increases the likelihood of biased CSR restatements that improve reported performance.

Title: The Effects of Corporate Social Responsibility and Wrongdoer Rank on Whistleblowing
Authors: Alisa G. Brink, C. Eller, Karen Y. Green
Abstract summary: This paper examines how corporate social responsibility and wrongdoer rank affect the likelihood of internal versus external whistleblowing.

Title: Female leadership in corporate social responsibility reporting: Effects on writing, readability and future social performance
Authors: M. Harjoto, I. Laksmana, W. E. Lee
Abstract summary: Female leadership in CSR reporting is associated with more readable and solidarity-focused reports, which are positively linked to future social performance.

Title: Corporate social responsibility report readability, credit ratings and cost of borrowing
Authors: Kun Yu, Priya S. Garg
Abstract summary: More readable CSR reports are associated with higher credit ratings and lower borrowing costs, suggesting they reduce information risk in credit markets.

Title: Social impacts reflected in CSR reports: Method of extraction and link to firms innovation capacity
Authors: Ivan Nechaev, D. Hain
Abstract summary: The paper presents a method to identify social impacts reflected in CSR reports and examines the relationship between a company's social impact and its innovation capacity.

Title: The Complementarity and Substitution Effects of CSR‐Focused Governance Mechanisms on CSR Decoupling
Authors: Mohammad Abweny, G. Afrifa, Abdullah Iqbal
Abstract summary: CSR-focused governance mechanisms like committees, reports, and contracting can complement or substitute each other in mitigating CSR decoupling.

Title: Do socially responsible audit firms provide higher audit quality? An investigation of corporate social responsibility activity in audit firms
Authors: Hanwen Chen, Siyi Liu, Xin Liu, Jiani Wang
Abstract summary: Socially responsible audit firms provide higher audit quality.

Title: Challenging Masculinity in CSR Disclosures: Silencing of Women’s Voices in Tanzania’s Mining Industry
Authors: S. Lauwo
Abstract summary: CSR reporting in the Tanzanian mining industry silences women's voices and reflects the masculinity of the industry.
